subject: Re: on screen representation of senior quikscript
msgSnippet: ... someone... ... rather ... Yes this makes good sense to me. As I say font editing is hardly my specialty and drawing a whole alphabet from the ground up is
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> othermale wrote:
> >
> >
> > Hi All,
> >
> > I wonder, does anyone know of an attempt to represent _senior_
> > quikscript typographically (ie enterable and viewable on a computer)?
> > I suppose this would be quite a bit more than just a font (eg the
> > challenge of joining the letter "roar"(aka "roe") and half letter
> > "zoo" in the abbreviation for Mrs. or the joining of "sis"("see") with
> > "pipe"("pea") ). I was toying with the notion of building an app for
> > this but if this or something better has already been done by
someone...
> >
>
> I am not a font expert, but I think you can design a font that joins
> characters together. I have seen such fonts done sucsessfully in
> Traditional Orthography (TO). You have to use anchors in order to get
> the letters to join. Actually getting the font to work properly might
> prove difficult--I can't say for sure.
>
> However, as Paige pointed out, I am working on a junior font right now.
> I have started a project at sourceforge, and it might make more sense
> for me to add you as a developer. That way, we have one place for
> Quikscript resources. Also, you may want to use some of my shapes
rather
> than create all of your own.
>
> Paul
>

Yes this makes good sense to me. As I say font editing is hardly my
specialty and drawing a whole alphabet from the ground up is not my
goal but working off of a good baseline with folks that know their
stuff would be quite cool.
The first concern that pops into my head however is character spacing:
junior needs it but senior can have none. Can one font do both?

-Tony
(BTW, are you finding fontforge a good tool?)
